As a guy living in Himalyas, I can say she is spitting facts!

There is a serious mistake here at 2:55 - I suggest issuing a correction!

Global warming does NOT increase oxygen (per volume) on Mt. Everest due to "higher temperatures increasing pressure". That would only be true in a closed container (where volume cannot change). In fact, it's the opposite: warming air EXPANDS (if it's not contained), so there will be LESS oxygen (per volume). That's why old prop airplanes need a less rich fuel mix on hot days (because there's less oxygen in the air to mix with the fuel), or higher up. That's why airplanes need more runway to take off (less air to give lift) on hot days (or higher up).

The real reason global warming increases air density on Mr. Everest is because the ENTIRE atmosphere expands, including the "thicker" parts lower down. This actually decreases pressure on ground level, pushes the "really thin" parts of the atmosphere higher up.

The discussion about climate change effects on air pressure at Everest's summit doesn't make a lot of sense. Firstly, gravity differences aren't that important. The idealized difference in the force of gravity between 8850m ASL and 0 ASL is less than 0.3%. Besides that, gravity isn't really changing and as the air warms, if anything I'd expect the volume of the atmosphere to increase meaning more air further away and experiencing the ever so slightly lower gravity further away. Why? Well the atmosphere isn't confined to a fixed volume, so it's not quite the same situation as a sealed bottle or something being heated and the pressure increasing. As the atmosphere warms, it can expand further up into space. That said, if the expectation is that temperature increase alone can directly lead to higher air pressures, then why do we see a belt of relatively low pressure around the equator where temperatures tend to be hotter? I'm not convinced. By far, the main reason for air pressure is the weight of the air above which is primarily dependent on its mass. Is climate change increasing the mass of the atmosphere? I'm thinking it could. As the temperature increases, the amount of water vapor in the atmosphere will increase. That's one source of additional atmospheric mass. Additionally, we're putting more carbon atoms into the air. For every carbon atom we put in the air we're roughly exchanging an oxygen molecule for a carbon dioxide molecule, which is about 37% heavier than oxygen. That's another source of additional atmospheric mass. These seem like more plausible explanations for why air pressure might increase as the planet warms. The atmosphere is gaining mass.

The statement air pressure tends to increase when temperature increases cannot be applied to global climate patterns. High pressure systems form over areas of low temperature due to contraction (areas experiencing winter) and low pressure systems form over areas experiencing summer, aka high temperature. The statement air pressure increases when temperature increases works when the heat source is strong enough acting on a smaller enclosed space, like a pressure cooker directly on a fire. So.... At standard pressure (1013.2 mb) and standard temp (about -43 °C at this alt), the density alt at the summit would be 8850 m. Everest’s summit’s true alt is 8849 m. If we make the temp 2 °C warmer at the summit, the density alt becomes 8904 m making it feel higher, not lower. I know I’m using pressure alt/keeping pressure constant, but the point is to show how temp affects density alt

That's because while Everest has the highest point above sea level, it is NOT the tallest mountain. The title of “tallest mountain in the word”, however, as measured from the base to its peak, belongs to Mauna Kea which has an altitude of only 4,205 meters (13,796 feet) above sea level.

The catch: it’s a dormant volcano on the island of Hawaii with the base about 19,700 feet below the surface of the Pacific Ocean. In other words, more than half of it is submerged. When you add everything up, Mauna Kea is over 10,000 meters tall, way taller than the 8,850 meters of Mount Everest — making it the world’s tallest mountain

The density of air decreases as temperature increases. Less dense air contains fewer molecules including oxygen. So as the temperature increases a climber gets less oxygen. She claims that air pressure increases as temperature increases. That is true for air in a closed vessel such as a pressure cooker. It is not true for an open system such as the air surrounding Mount Everest.

From a thermodymanic point of view, this makes the sorroundings of Mount Everest work as a closed system, not an open system as one would think (In case I am wrong, you are welcomed to thrash my comment)
